excerpt: Ruins of a temple known for creative architecture such as a moving stone chariot & musical pillars.
detail_description: The Shree Vijaya Vitthala Temple, dating back to the 15th century, is a massive complex showcasing the architectural brilliance of the Vijayanagara empire. Dedicated to Lord Vitthala, an incarnation of Lord Vishnu, it features various shrines and halls including the Maha Mantapa, Kalayana Mantapa, Devi Shrine, Utsav Mantapa and Ranga Mantapa. The iconic stone chariot in its courtyard is a striking structure that was once movable.
name: Shree Vijaya Vitthala Temple

excerpt: Peak with hiking trails leading to a popular lookout for watching sunrises & sunsets.
detail_description: Matanga Hill is a popular peak in Hampi with hiking trails that lead to a well-known lookout for watching breathtaking sunrises and sunsets. The area is rich in historical monuments such as the Elephant Stables, Queens Bath, Octagonal Bath, and Stepped Tank. Visitors can also enjoy jamming sessions while watching the sunset at Matanga Hills or opt for a quieter evening at Malyavanta Hill, which offers similar scenic beauty but with fewer crowds.
name: Matanga Hill

detail_description: Hampi Bazaar, located in the town of Hampi, was once the bustling capital of the Vijayanagara empire. Today, it remains a vibrant local market where visitors can explore stalls offering various goods. The area is also home to the famous Virupaksha temple and other sacred sites in what is known as the Sacred Quarter. One notable attraction near the bazaar is the Monolith Bull, a large ancient structure situated in a pavilion opposite the Virupaksha Temple.
name: Hampi Bazaar

excerpt: A UNESCO Heritage Site, this 7th-century Hindu temple has a gateway tower, courtyards & dining hall.
detail_description: Virupaksha Temple is situated in front of the bustling Virupaksha Bazaar, also known as Hampi Bazaar. This historic market spans over a kilometer and holds the distinction of being one of India's earliest organized retail spaces. While not extravagant, it offers a glimpse into ancient commercial practices.
name: Virupaksha Temple, Hampi

excerpt: A UNESCO Heritage Site, this 7th-century Hindu temple has a gateway tower, courtyards & dining hall.
detail_description: Virupaksha Temple in Hampi is a UNESCO Heritage Site dating back to the 7th century. The temple features a gateway tower, courtyards, and a dining hall. It is dedicated to Lord Shiva and his consort Pampadevi and is still actively used for worship. Visitors can also enjoy a trek to the nearby hilltop for stunning sunrise views of the surrounding rocky hills, river, and ancient temples.
name: Virupaksha Temple, Hampi

excerpt: Numerous ancient temple structures sit atop this hillside known for its ruins & striking panoramas.
detail_description: Hemakuta Hill Temple is a must-visit in Hampi, offering ancient temple structures, ruins of Vijayanagara, and breathtaking panoramic views. The area is rich with UNESCO World Heritage sites and is popular among photographers. Visitors can also enjoy rock climbing and witness stunning sunrises and sunsets from this vantage point. Additionally, the surrounding landscape adorned with temples and rocky hills provides a surreal backdrop for exploration.
name: Hemakuta Hill Temple

excerpt: Indo-Islamic style structure used as the stables for the royal elephants of the Vijayanagara Empire.
detail_description: The Elephant Stables in Hampi, India, are a remarkable example of Indo-Islamic architecture and were once used to house the royal elephants of the Vijayanagara Empire. This well-preserved 16th-century structure boasts 11 intricately carved rooms set in grassy grounds. Despite the entry fee, visitors find it worth it for the chance to explore the cool stone buildings and relax on the expansive lawn.
name: Elephant Stables

excerpt: Ancient stone palace structure with tranquil gardens, arches & elaborate carvings.
detail_description: Lotus Mahal, also known as Kamal Mahal or Chitragani Mahal, is a stunning structure located within the Zenana Enclosure of the Vijayanagara Empire. This ancient stone palace boasts tranquil gardens, arches, and elaborate carvings that showcase a beautiful blend of Hindu and Islamic architecture. The two-storied elegant pavilion features massive pillars, exquisite stucco mouldings, and intricate carvings of artistic patterns and birds on its walls.
name: Lotus Mahal

excerpt: 15th-century Hindu temple with intricate carvings depicting animals, deities & people.
detail_description: Hazara Raama Temple is a 15th-century Hindu temple in Hampi, known for its intricate carvings depicting animals, deities, and people. The temple features a thousand frescoes portraying scenes from the Ramayana, leaving visitors speechless. It is dedicated to Lord Rama and also houses relics of Lord Krishna.
name: Hazara Raama Temple

detail_description: Shri Lakshmi Narasimha Temple is one of the must-visit attractions in Hampi, known for its 6.7-meter monolith statue of Lord Narasimha, an avatar of Lord Vishnu. This half-man half-lion statue showcases the exceptional craftsmanship of Vijayanagara artisans and continues to captivate travelers from all over the world.
name: Shri Lakshmi Narasimha Temple

detail_description: Hippie Island, also known as Hippie Island 2.0, is a popular destination for its stunning sunset views and relaxing atmosphere. However, due to flooding and subsequent government action, all the restaurants on the island have been demolished. As a result, tourists have been evacuated and only the sunset point remains. While some establishments have relocated to the Sanapur side of the island, they are not as concentrated or well-established as before.
name: Hippie river island

excerpt: Hampi or Hampe is the city in the Vijayanagara district in the Indian state of Karnataka. Located along the Tungabhadra River in the east and center part of the state, Hampi is near the city of Hospet. It is famous for hosting the Hampi Group of Monuments with the Virupaksha Temple, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Wikipedia.
detail_description: Hampi, also known as Vijayanagara, is a town located in the Indian state of Karnataka. Situated along the Tungabhadra River near the city of Hosapete, this area is rich in history and natural beauty. The landscape is characterized by massive grey boulders shaped by water and wind into various forms, creating a unique and picturesque setting.
name: Hampi

excerpt: Historic temple featuring elaborate carvings & an enormous sculpture of Lord Ganesha.
detail_description: Kadalekalu Ganesha is a significant religious site in Hampi, known for its traditional stone architecture and historical importance. The temple houses a massive 15-foot monolithic statue of Lord Ganesha, carved entirely from granite. This impressive sculpture is believed to be one of the largest in the world and is a testament to the skill and artistry of ancient craftsmen.
name: Kadalekalu Ganesha

excerpt: Hindu temple accessed by climbing hundreds of steps, known for a rock carving of Lord Hanuman.
detail_description: Yantrodharaka Hanuman Temple, located in the captivating temple town of Hampi, is a sacred Hindu site dedicated to Lord Hanuman. Accessible by climbing hundreds of steps to the top of Anjaneya Hill, this 500-year-old temple offers stunning views and a serene atmosphere. The temple also houses a rock carving of Lord Hanuman and is situated amidst the remains of the historical city of Vijayanagar.
name: Sri Yantrodharaka Hanuman Temple, Hampi

excerpt: Remains of a 14th-century Hindu temple built below ground level with pillared halls & a courtyard.
detail_description: The Underground Shiva Temple in Hampi is a fascinating 14th-century Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Shiva. Situated below ground level, the core areas of the temple are typically submerged, making access to the inner parts restricted. Visitors can experience the marvel of wide steps leading to the interior, where a massive hall with cubical pillars supporting the roof awaits. Depending on water levels, access to the sanctum area may be possible, providing an exhilarating encounter with bats flying around.
name: Underground Shiva Temple

excerpt: 16th-century temple ruins with elaborately carved stone pillars & towers & a sacred water tank.
detail_description: Hampi Shri Krishna Swami Temple is a 16th-century temple complex with intricately carved stone pillars and towers, as well as a sacred water tank. The site includes various temple complexes such as Narasimha, Ganesa, Hemakuta group of temples, Achyutaraya temple complex, Vitthala temple complex, Pattabhirama temple complex, and Lotus Mahal complex.
name: Hampi Shri Krishna Temple

detail_description: When visiting Hampi, don't miss out on the unique experience of a Coracle Ride. This traditional round boat offers an affordable and fun way to cross the river, reminiscent of olden days. The ride provides a refreshing and nature-immersed experience, with the opportunity to see temples from the water. While some may find it reminiscent of Bollywood movies, it's truly an authentic and enjoyable activity in Hampi tourism.
name: Coracle Ride (chakra terta)

detail_description: Hanuman Temple is a small and active temple located on the banks of Thungabadra. Visitors are required to remove their footwear before entering. The temple offers a picturesque view of the river and its currents, making it a great spot to relax and enjoy the scenery. It is situated near Vijaya Vittalla Temple, offering visitors the opportunity to see old archaeological ruins across the river as well as the Monkey Temple in one frame.
name: Hanuman Temple

detail_description: Sunset Point, located on Hippie Island in Hampi, is a mesmerizing destination that offers a breathtaking view of the setting sun. The natural wonder captivates visitors with its tranquil and picturesque location. It's a 10-minute hike to the top, but the spectacular view of Hampi town and nearby boulders along with the sunset makes it worth it. This spot is also known for its beautiful sunrise and lush green rice fields.
name: Sunset point - Hippie Island

excerpt: Royal women once lived in this historic, architecturally notable walled compound a serene setting.
detail_description: The Zanana Enclosure in Hampi is a historically significant walled compound that once housed the royal women of the Vijayanagara Empire. This secluded area provided privacy and security for the queens, allowing them to engage in cultural and artistic pursuits.
name: Zanana Enclosure

excerpt: 15th-century stone scale that supposedly weighed the king against gold that he gave to the priests.
detail_description: In the ancient city of Hampi, India, lies the King's Balance, a 15th-century stone scale with two carved granite pillars and a balance beam. Legend has it that kings would weigh themselves against precious metals here, which were then distributed to the poor. This historic site offers a glimpse into Vijayanagara architecture and holds cultural significance as a symbol of royal offerings to the divine.
name: Kings Balance

excerpt: Ornate carving of a divine, Hindu vehicle situated on the grounds of the Vijaya Vitthala Temple.
detail_description: The Stone Chariot in Hampi is a renowned religious site located within the Vijaya Vitthala Temple. This UNESCO World Heritage site showcases incredible architecture and intricate carvings, reflecting advanced ancient culture and technology. Visitors can reach the chariot by walking or taking an e-buggy from the parking area. The short walk offers a pleasant experience, but it's important to stay hydrated as there are no water facilities near the chariot itself.
name: The Stone Chariot (Hampi)

detail_description: The Palace of Vira Harihara in Hampi is a historical site that offers a glimpse into the grandeur and royal lifestyle of the Vijayanagar monarchs. Although only the foundation base layouts remain within the fortified area of the Royal Enclosure, it still evokes admiration and imagination. The ruins are a testament to the once colossal structure and provide insight into the history of the great Vijayanagar Empire.
name: Palace of Vira Harihara

detail_description: Located in Hampi, the Shiva Temple is a unique underground temple dedicated to Lord Shiva. Situated several meters below ground level, the sanctum and core parts of the temple are often submerged in water, restricting access to inner areas. Visitors can descend stairs to view the Shiv Linga and Nandi Idol inside. The temple is dedicated to Lord Virupaksha, a form of Shiva, and is made from black stone. Surrounding gardens provide a peaceful place for relaxation.
name: Shiva Temple

excerpt: This temple is an open pavilion with a statue of the Hindu god Ganesha carved from a single rock.
detail_description: Saasivekaalu Ganesha, located in the Hampi region of Karnataka, India, is a historic monument and a beloved site for devotees. The eight feet tall monolithic statue of Lord Ganesha is carved from a single rock and is known for its intricate details and finely carved features. It holds significance as the remover of obstacles and bestower of wisdom in Hindu mythology.
name: Saasivekaalu Ganesha | Hampi

detail_description: Sri Kodandarama Temple, located on the banks of the Tungabhadra River in Hampi, holds great religious significance. The temple is believed to be the site where Laxmana crowned Sugreeva as the King of Kishkinda after Lord Rama killed Vali.
name: Sri Kodandarama Temple

excerpt: Massive monolithic sculpture of a bull, set in a 2-story pavilion framed by huge boulders.
detail_description: Nandi, a massive monolithic sculpture of a bull, is located near the Hampi Bazaar. This remarkable piece of architecture is housed in a two-story pavilion and is believed to be the vehicle for Lord Shiva in Hindu culture. Despite being partially weathered, it showcases the creativity of the ancient Vijayanagara people. The bull stands facing the Virupaksha Temple and has stood for almost 500 years as a symbol of strength and endurance.
name: Nandi

detail_description: OLD CHILL OUT Ganesh RESTAURANT is a laid-back and popular spot near the Hampi Bazaar, known for its hippie vibe and low tables with floor seating. The restaurant offers a diverse menu featuring Indian and international dishes, making it a favorite among backpackers and travelers. It's a cozy place where locals and tourists alike can enjoy delicious food and drinks in a relaxed atmosphere.
name: OLD CHILL OUT Ganesh RESTAURANT

detail_description: Trishul Restaurant, located in Hampi, is a popular dining spot offering a diverse range of Indian, Chinese, and International dishes. Renowned for its Italian Pizza, Chinese Noodles, Mexican Enchilada, Israeli Hummus Falafel, and Tibetian Momo specialties, it attracts both locals and tourists. Situated conveniently near the Virupaksha temple with a pleasant ambiance, the restaurant may take some time to serve food as everything is made to order.
name: Trishul Restaurant

detail_description: The Temples on Hemakuta Hill in Hampi are a must-visit for tourists. This cluster of ancient temples, archways, and pavilions dates back to the 9th to 14th century, before the Vijayanagara Empire was established. The hill features around 20 small temples with intricate architecture and offers a stunning view of the sunset. Visitors can also find motifs and carvings of Hanuman throughout the site, making it especially significant for Hanuman devotees.
name: Temples on Hemakuta Hill

detail_description: Krishna Bazaar is a vibrant and bustling market located in the heart of the city. It offers a wide variety of goods, including colorful textiles, traditional handicrafts, aromatic spices, and fresh produce. The lively atmosphere is filled with the sounds of vendors calling out their wares and shoppers bargaining for the best deals. Visitors can immerse themselves in the local culture as they explore the maze of stalls and interact with friendly merchants.
name: Krishna Bazaar

detail_description: The Vijayanagar ruins are a historical site in Hampi, India, featuring the remains of the once-thriving capital of the Vijayanagara Empire. Visitors can explore impressive structures such as temples, palaces, and market areas spread across a vast area. The ruins offer a glimpse into the empire's architectural and cultural heritage, with intricate carvings and stunning stone monuments.
name: Vijayanagar ruins

detail_description: Hampi Bazar is a unique and tranquil destination that offers a distinct experience from the usual hustle and bustle of Hampi. It's an ideal place for those seeking a peaceful retreat away from the crowds. Whether you're a frequent visitor to Hampi or it's your first time, this area provides a different perspective on the region, making it worth exploring.
name: Hampi bazar

excerpt: Hampi is the city in the Vijayanagara district in the Indian state of Karnataka. Located along the Tungabhadra River in the east and center part of the state, Hampi is near the city of Hospet. It is famous for hosting the Hampi Group of Monuments with the Virupaksha Temple, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Wikipedia.
detail_description: Nestled in the heart of Karnataka, Hampi, also known as Vijayanagara and historically referred to as Kishkindha from the Ramayana era, is a captivating destination that enchants travelers with its rich heritage. This picturesque town lies along the banks of the Tungabhadra River and is close to Hosapete. Renowned for its stunning ruins from the Vijayanagara Empire, Hampi has earned recognition as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, making it an essential stop for history enthusiasts.
name: Hampi

detail_description: Nestled in the historic landscape of Hampi, Sri Guddada Moola Virupaksha Gudi is a captivating temple dedicated to Lord Virupaksha, an incarnation of Lord Shiva. Dating back to the 7th century, this ancient shrine remains active and draws pilgrims seeking spiritual solace. The temple's sanctum houses a linga that is believed to be connected to the divine source known as "Guddada Moola," enhancing its sacredness.
name: Sri Guddada Moola Virupaksha Gudi

excerpt: Ruins of an ornate, historic bathing chamber used by the king & his wives, with an outdoor pool.
detail_description: The Queen's Bathhouse in Hampi, Karnataka is a fascinating historical site that offers a glimpse into the opulent lifestyle of the kings and queens of the Vijayanagara Empire. This ornate bathing chamber, once used by royalty, features impressive architecture and intricate design. The outdoor pool adds to its allure. It's recommended to visit this as part of a group tour covering other monuments in the area.
name: Queen's Bathhouse || Hampi

detail_description: Mahanavami (Dasara) Dibba is a highly recommended tourist destination that offers an enriching experience. Engaging with the services of the guides here proves to be beneficial as they explain each carving on the monuments, narrate the story of how Dasara originated and was celebrated, and provide insights into the significance of the platform for kings. From atop, one can witness diverse areas designated for different festivities.
name: Mahaanavami Dibba - Hampi

detail_description: Gudi Gajashale, also known as the Elephant Stables, is a significant attraction within the Palace of Vira Harihara in Hampi. This well-preserved structure served as shelter for the royal elephants of the Vijayanagara Empire. The architecture reflects intricate details and an emphasis on design, showcasing the empire's reverence for these majestic animals. Visitors can witness 11 domed chambers, some interconnected, with a specially decorated and spacious central chamber.
name: - Gudi Gajashale

excerpt: Striking 16th-century temple ruins with ornamental details, carvings & sculpted pillars.
detail_description: The Shri Achyutaraaya Swamy Temple is a stunning 16th-century ruin adorned with intricate details, carvings, and sculpted pillars. Situated at the southern end of Sule Bazaar, this temple dates back to 1534 and stands as one of the last grand monuments built before the decline of Hampi.
name: Shri Achyutarya Swamy Temple

excerpt: Set atop a forest, this sprawling sanctuary provides public tours & up-close views of sloth bears.
name: Daroji Sloth Bear Sanctuary

detail_description: In the ancient city of Hampi, the Stone Doors stand as a testament to the grandeur of the Vijayanagara Empire. These impressive monolith doors were once part of the Royal Enclosure and are now among the prominent remnants of that era. Measuring 18 feet each, these massive stone doors were operated by elephants and likely served as an entrance to an important royal building. Although they no longer function, they continue to captivate visitors with their historical significance and intricate craftsmanship.
name: Stone Doors

detail_description: The Purandara Daasara Mantapa, located in the historic town of Hampi, India, is a simple yet significant structure dedicated to Lord Vitthala. Built on the river bed without a foundation, this small shrine has survived for many years. It hosts an annual Carnatic music festival in memory of Sri Purandara Dasa and offers a serene ambiance for visitors to appreciate its historical and cultural importance.
name: Purandara Daasa and Kanakadasa Mantapa

detail_description: Bhimas Gate, situated in Hampi, Karnataka, is positioned 5 km southeast of Hampi Bazar. This fortified entrance is a part of the Vijayanagara complex from the 14th to 17th century CE. The inner walls exhibit a sculpture of Bhima from the Mahabharatha epic. The construction employs intricate tactics to create blind spots for potential invaders.
name: Bhima's Gateway
